Award.AwardTitle: Building an Effective Service-Oriented Cyberinfrastructure Portal to Support Sustained Polar Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop components of a polar cyberinfrastructure (CI) to support researchers and users for data discovery and access. The main goal is to provide tools that will enable a better access to polar data and information, hence allowing to spend more time on analysis and research, and significantly less time on discover and searching. At the end of the project, the PIs will deliver a large-scale web crawler to continuously mine the Internet to discover dispersed polar data and a quality monitoring tool allowing polar data reformulation. Beside identifying polar data in major data repositories, the crawler will be able to bring individual hidden resources forward, hence increasing the discoverability of polar data. Quality and assessment of data resources will be analyzed, providing a key tool for not only identifying issues but also to connect the research community with optimal data resources.
The project will impact several disciplines, users and communities of practice - within and beyond the polar sciences. The broader impacts include the improved discoverability of data and better access so that the time spent searching the data could be reduced (and hence used for research purposes). The data quality and crawler components of the work will be made available to the scientific community to serve future purposes and support additional work. Moreover, the project will also contribute to the growth of a 'cyberpolar' community, through the collaboration of computer scientists focusing on specific polar issues. Results will be incorporated into lessons and hands-on experience for undergraduate and graduate students through classroom activities and two PhD students will be involved full time for the duration of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF project aims at developing new cyberinfrastructure tools for discovering, searching and visualizing disparate data resources covering polar region to support polar studies, ranging from polar climate change to biodiversity, from endangered species to vegetation significance studies. Over the three-year course, we have successfully developed two cyber tools -- PolarHub (http://polar.geodacenter.org/polarhub3) and Polar CI portal (http://polar.geodacenter.org/gci2). The PolarHub tool has the ability to conduct a web-scale crawling to discover distributed data and services covering polar regions. Search, data preview, and statistics functions are developed to improve comprehension of the vast amount of dataset. The Polar CI portal goes one step further to support the integrated analysis and visualization of these datasets. These two portals are interconnected: in PolarHub, if a user wants to view the content of a dataset, he can open the CI portal by a single click. Meanwhile, the Polar CI portal's backend database is cross-linked with PolarHub, such that all data found by PolarHub can be searched from Polar CI portal for visual analytics. In today's big data era, the PolarHub will serve well as the surfboard for big data deluge. In addition, the visualization and analysis capability in the Polar CI has fostered the discovery of underlying patterns and new knowledge. Benefiting from this tool development which reduces the time used for data collection and analysis, the scientific discovery process can be substantially accelerated. 

Besides the tool development, the PIs have organized 9 polar CI related sessions in international conferences such as AGU and AAG (Association of American Geographers) to foster the discussions between domain scientists and computer scientists to move forward the polar CI research. 

This project have also resulted in 26 publications, including 2 book chapters, 14 peer-reviewed journal publications, 8 conference papers/reports, and 2 PhD dissertations. 11 young scholars were trained in the area of cyberinfrastructure and data science during this project. They are 1 postdoctral scholar and 10 graduate students (8 at PhD level and 2 at MS level). Two PhDs (majoring in Earth System and Geoinformation Science) and two masters (one in Computer Science, one in Geography) graduated from this project. The PI and the postdoctoral scholar are both young female scholars, their growth in career have increased the representation of women in STEM-related disciplines.
